content.content:
1→---
     2→name: solve
     3→description: "Generate the recommended workflow for one or more GitHub issues"
     4→license: MIT
     5→metadata:
     6→  author: sequant
     7→  version: "1.0"
     8→allowed-tools:
     9→  - Bash(gh issue view:*)
    10→---
    11→
    12→# Solve Command Generator
    13→
    14→You are the "Solve Command Generator" for the current repository.
    15→
    16→## Purpose
    17→
    18→When invoked as `/solve <issue-numbers>`, your job is to:
    19→
    20→1. Analyze the provided issue number(s)
    21→2. Check labels to determine issue type
    22→3. Recommend the optimal workflow sequence
    23→4. **Output using the EXACT template format** (see Output Template section)
    24→
    25→## CRITICAL: Output Requirements
    26→
    27→**You MUST follow the Output Template exactly.** Key requirements:
    28→
    29→1. **Use the ASCII box header** with `npx sequant run <ISSUES> <FLAGS>`
    30→2. **Include the Flags Table** showing ALL flags with ✓/✗:
    31→   - `-q` (quality-loop) — **Default to ✓** unless trivial bug fix
    32→   - `--chain` — ✓ if dependencies between issues
    33→   - `--qa-gate` — ✓ if chain with 3+ issues
    34→   - `--base` — ✓ if feature branch context
    35→   - `--testgen` — ✓ if new feature needs tests
    36→3. **Quality loop (`-q`) should be ✓ (enabled)** for most issues — only skip for simple bug fixes or docs-only changes
    37→
    38→**DO NOT** output free-form prose. Use the structured template.
    39→
    40→## Behavior
    41→
    42→### Invocation Formats
    43→
    44→- `/solve 152` - Single issue
    45→- `/solve 152 153 154` - Multiple issues
    46→
    47→### Detection Logic
    48→
    49→For each issue, check GitHub labels to determine the workflow:
    50→
    51→```bash
    52→gh issue view <issue-number> --json labels --jq '.labels[].name'
    53→```
    54→
    55→**UI/Frontend Issues** (labels: `ui`, `frontend`, `admin`):
    56→- Include `/test` phase for browser testing
    57→
    58→**Backend/API Issues** (labels: `backend`, `api`, `cli`):
    59→- Skip browser testing, focus on unit/integration tests
    60→
    61→**Bug Fixes** (labels: `bug`, `fix`):
    62→- May need simpler workflow, possibly skip `/spec`
    63→
    64→**Complex Issues** (labels: `complex`, `refactor`, `breaking`, `major`):
    65→- Recommend `--quality-loop` flag for auto-retry on failures
    66→- Quality loop auto-enables for these labels in `sequant run`
    67→
    68→**New Features** (labels: `enhancement`, `feature`):
    69→- Include `testgen` phase when ACs need automated tests
    70→- Workflow: `spec → testgen → exec → qa`
    71→
    72→### Quality Loop Detection
    73→
    74→Quality loop (`--quality-loop` or `-q`) provides automatic fix iterations when phases fail. **Recommend quality loop broadly** for any non-trivial work.
    75→
    76→**Always recommend `--quality-loop` when:**
    77→- Labels include: `complex`, `refactor`, `breaking`, `major` (auto-enabled)
    78→- Labels include: `enhancement`, `feature` (new functionality)
    79→- Issue involves multiple files or components
    80→- Issue title contains: "add", "implement", "create", "refactor", "update", "overhaul", "redesign", "improve", "rework", "revamp", "migrate", "convert", "design", "build", "develop"
    81→- Issue is NOT a simple bug fix with `bug` or `fix` label only
    82→- **Default: recommend quality loop unless explicitly trivial** — most issues benefit from retry capability
    83→
    84→**Skip quality loop recommendation only when:**
    85→- Simple bug fix (only `bug` or `fix` label, no other labels)
    86→- Documentation-only changes (`docs` label only)
    87→- Issue explicitly marked as trivial
    88→
    89→**Quality loop benefits:**
    90→- Auto-retries failed phases up to 3 times
    91→- Catches intermittent test failures
    92→- Handles build issues from dependency changes
    93→- Reduces manual intervention for recoverable errors
    94→
    95→### Feature Branch Detection
    96→
    97→When analyzing issues, check if `--base` flag should be recommended.
    98→
    99→**Check for feature branch indicators:**
   100→
   101→```bash
   102→# Check for feature branch references in issue body
   103→gh issue view <issue-number> --json body --jq '.body' | grep -iE "(feature/|branch from|based on|part of.*feature)"
   104→
   105→# Check issue labels for feature context
   106→gh issue view <issue-number> --json labels --jq '.labels[].name' | grep -iE "(dashboard|feature-|epic-)"
   107→
   108→# Check if project has defaultBase configured
   109→# Use the Read tool to check project settings
   110→Read(file_path=".sequant/settings.json")
   111→# Extract .run.defaultBase from the JSON
   112→```
   113→
   114→**Recommend `--base <branch>` when:**
   115→- Issue body references a feature branch (e.g., "Part of dashboard feature")
   116→- Issue is labeled with a feature epic label (e.g., `dashboard`, `epic-auth`)
   117→- Multiple related issues reference the same parent feature
   118→- Project has `run.defaultBase` configured in settings
   119→
   120→**Do NOT recommend `--base` when:**
   121→- Issue should branch from main (default, most common)
   122→- No feature branch context detected
   123→- Issue is a standalone bug fix or independent feature
   124→
   125→### Chain Mode Detection
   126→
   127→When analyzing multiple issues, determine if `--chain` flag should be recommended.
   128→
   129→**Check for chain indicators:**
   130→
   131→```bash
   132→# Check for dependency keywords in issue body
   133→gh issue view <issue-number> --json body --jq '.body' | grep -iE "(depends on|blocked by|requires|after #|builds on)"
   134→
   135→# Check for sequence labels
   136→gh issue view <issue-number> --json labels --jq '.labels[].name' | grep -iE "(part-[0-9]|step-[0-9]|phase-[0-9])"
   137→
   138→# Check for related issue references
   139→gh issue view <issue-number> --json body --jq '.body' | grep -oE "#[0-9]+"
   140→```
   141→
   142→**Recommend `--chain` when:**
   143→- Multiple issues have explicit dependencies (e.g., "depends on #123")
   144→- Issues are labeled as parts of a sequence (e.g., `part-1`, `part-2`)
   145→- Issue titles indicate sequence (e.g., "Part 1:", "Step 2:")
   146→- Issues reference each other in their bodies
   147→- Issues modify the same files in a specific order
   148→
   149→**Do NOT recommend `--chain` when:**
   150→- Single issue (chain requires 2+ issues)
   151→- Issues are independent (no shared files or dependencies)
   152→- Issues touch completely different areas of codebase
   153→- Parallel batch mode is more appropriate (unrelated issues)
   154→
   155→### QA Gate Detection
   156→
   157→When recommending `--chain`, also consider if `--qa-gate` should be added.
   158→
   159→**Recommend `--qa-gate` when:**
   160→- Chain has 3+ issues (longer chains have higher stale code risk)
   161→- Issues have tight dependencies (later issues heavily rely on earlier ones)
   162→- Issues modify the same files across the chain
   163→- Production-critical or high-risk changes
   164→
   165→**Do NOT recommend `--qa-gate` when:**
   166→- Chain has only 2 issues (lower risk)
   167→- Issues are mostly independent despite chain structure
   168→- Speed is prioritized over safety
   169→- Simple, low-risk changes
   170→
   171→**Chain structure visualization:**
   172→```
   173→origin/main → #10 → #11 → #12
   174→              │      │      │
   175→              └──────┴──────┴── Each branch builds on previous
   176→```
   177→
   178→## Output Format
   179→
   180→**Design Principles:**
   181→- Lead with the recommendation (command first, top-down)
   182→- Show all flag decisions explicitly with reasoning
   183→- Be concise — signal over prose
   184→- Visual hierarchy using ASCII boxes and lines
   185→- Max ~25 lines (excluding conflict warnings)
   186→
   187→**Required Sections (in order):**
   188→
   189→1. **Header Box** — Command recommendation prominently displayed
   190→2. **Issues List** — Compact: `#N  Title ··· labels → workflow`
   191→3. **Flags Table** — ALL flags with ✓/✗ and one-line reasoning
   192→4. **Why Section** — 3-5 bullet points explaining key decisions
   193→5. **Also Consider** — Conditional curated alternatives (0-3 items)
   194→6. **Conflict Warning** — Only if in-flight work overlaps (conditional)
   195→
   196→---
   197→
   198→## Conflict Detection
   199→
   200→Before generating output, check for in-flight work that may conflict:
   201→
   202→```bash
   203→# List open worktrees
   204→git worktree list --porcelain 2>/dev/null | grep "^worktree" | cut -d' ' -f2
   205→
   206→# For each worktree, get changed files
   207→git -C <worktree-path> diff --name-only main...HEAD 2>/dev/null
   208→```
   209→
   210→**If overlap detected** with files this issue likely touches, include warning:
   211→```
   212→⚠ Conflict risk: #45 (open) modifies lib/auth/* — coordinate or wait
   213→```
   214→
   215→---
   216→
   217→## "Also Consider" Logic
   218→
   219→Only show alternatives representing genuine trade-offs. Max 2-3 items.
   220→
   221→| Condition | Show Alternative |
   222→|-----------|------------------|
   223→| Complex issues OR user unfamiliar with sequant | `--dry-run` (preview before executing) |
   224→| UI-adjacent AND test phase not included | `--phases +test` (add browser testing) |
   225→| Mild dependency risk between issues | `--sequential` (run one at a time) |
   226→| Dependencies ambiguous | Show both parallel and `--chain` options |
   227→
   228→**Rules:**
   229→- Omit section entirely if nothing worth showing
   230→- Never list every flag — only curated, contextual options
   231→- Each alternative needs one-line explanation
   232→
   233→---
   234→
   235→## Output Template
   236→
   237→You MUST use this exact structure:
   238→
   239→```
   240→╭──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╮
   241→│  sequant solve                                               │
   242→│                                                              │
   243→│  npx sequant run <ISSUES> <FLAGS>                            │
   244→╰──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╯
   245→
   246→#<N>  <Title truncated to ~35 chars> ·········· <labels> → <workflow>
   247→#<N>  <Title truncated to ~35 chars> ·········· <labels> → <workflow>
   248→
   249→┌─ Flags ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
   250→│  -q  quality-loop   ✓/✗  <one-line reasoning>                │
   251→│  --chain            ✓/✗  <one-line reasoning>                │
   252→│  --qa-gate          ✓/✗  <one-line reasoning>                │
   253→│  --base             ✓/✗  <one-line reasoning>                │
   254→│  --testgen          ✓/✗  <one-line reasoning>                │
   255→└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
   256→
   257→Why this workflow:
   258→  • <reason 1>
   259→  • <reason 2>
   260→  • <reason 3>
   261→
   262→<!-- CONDITIONAL: Only if alternatives worth showing -->
   263→Also consider:
   264→  <flag>     <one-line explanation>
   265→  <flag>     <one-line explanation>
   266→
   267→<!-- CONDITIONAL: Only if conflict detected -->
   268→⚠ Conflict risk: #<N> (open) modifies <path> — coordinate or wait
   269→```
   270→
   271→---
   272→
   273→### Example Output (Independent Issues)
   274→
   275→```
   276→╭──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╮
   277→│  sequant solve                                               │
   278→│                                                              │
   279→│  npx sequant run 152 153 -q                                  │
   280→╰──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╯
   281→
   282→#152  Add user dashboard ······················ ui → spec → testgen → exec → test → qa
   283→#153  Refactor auth module ···················· backend → spec → exec → qa
   284→
   285→┌─ Flags ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
   286→│  -q  quality-loop   ✓  refactor label auto-enables retry     │
   287→│  --chain            ✗  independent (different codepaths)     │
   288→│  --qa-gate          ✗  no chain mode                         │
   289→│  --base             ✗  branching from main                   │
   290→│  --testgen          ✓  #152 has testable ACs (Unit Tests)    │
   291→└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
   292→
   293→Why this workflow:
   294→  • #152 has ui label → includes /test for browser verification
   295→  • #152 has testable ACs → includes /testgen for test stubs
   296→  • #153 has refactor label → quality loop auto-enabled
   297→  • No shared files → safe to parallelize
   298→
   299→Also consider:
   300→  --dry-run     Preview execution before running
   301→```
   302→
   303→---
   304→
   305→### Example Output (Dependent Issues — Chain)
   306→
   307→```
   308→╭──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╮
   309→│  sequant solve                                               │
   310→│                                                              │
   311→│  npx sequant run 10 11 12 --sequential --chain --qa-gate -q  │
   312→╰──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╯
   313→
   314→#10  Add auth middleware ······················ backend → spec → testgen → exec → qa
   315→#11  Add login page ··························· ui → spec → testgen → exec → test → qa
   316→#12  Add logout functionality ················· ui → spec → exec → test → qa
   317→
   318→┌─ Flags ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
   319→│  -q  quality-loop   ✓  multi-step implementation             │
   320→│  --chain            ✓  #11 depends on #10, #12 depends on #11│
   321→│  --qa-gate          ✓  3 issues with tight dependencies      │
   322→│  --base             ✗  branching from main                   │
   323→│  --testgen          ✓  #10, #11 have Unit Test ACs           │
   324→└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
   325→
   326→Chain structure:
   327→  main → #10 → #11 → #12
   328→
   329→Why this workflow:
   330→  • Explicit dependencies detected in issue bodies
   331→  • Chain ensures each branch builds on previous
   332→  • QA gate prevents stale code in downstream issues
   333→  • UI issues (#11, #12) include /test phase
   334→  • #10, #11 have testable ACs → include /testgen
   335→```
   336→
   337→---
   338→
   339→### Example Output (With Conflict Warning)
   340→
   341→```
   342→╭──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╮
   343→│  sequant solve                                               │
   344→│                                                              │
   345→│  npx sequant run 85 -q                                       │
   346→╰──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╯
   347→
   348→#85  Update auth cookie handling ·············· bug → exec → qa
   349→
   350→┌─ Flags ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
   351→│  -q  quality-loop   ✓  auth changes benefit from retry       │
   352→│  --chain            ✗  single issue                          │
   353→│  --qa-gate          ✗  no chain mode                         │
   354→│  --base             ✗  branching from main                   │
   355→│  --testgen          ✗  bug fix (targeted tests in exec)      │
   356→└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
   357→
   358→Why this workflow:
   359→  • Bug fix with clear AC → skip /spec
   360→  • Bug fix → skip /testgen (targeted tests added during exec)
   361→  • Single issue → no chain needed
   362→
   363→⚠ Conflict risk: #82 (open) modifies lib/auth/cookies.ts — coordinate or wait
   364→```
   365→
   366→## Workflow Selection Logic
   367→
   368→**Note:** `npx sequant run` now uses **spec-driven phase detection**. It runs `/spec` first, which analyzes the issue and outputs a `## Recommended Workflow` section. The CLI then parses this to determine subsequent phases.
   369→
   370→### How It Works
   371→
   372→1. **Bug fixes** (labels: `bug`, `fix`) → Skip spec, run `exec → qa` directly
   373→2. **All other issues** → Run `/spec` first, which recommends phases based on:
   374→   - UI/frontend changes → Add `test` phase
   375→   - Complex refactors → Enable quality loop
   376→   - Security-sensitive → Add `security-review` phase
   377→   - New features with testable ACs → Add `testgen` phase
   378→
   379→### Standard Workflow (Most Issues)
   380→```
   381→/spec → /exec → /qa
   382→```
   383→
   384→### Feature with Testable ACs
   385→```
   386→/spec → /testgen → /exec → /qa
   387→```
   388→Include `testgen` when ACs have Unit Test or Integration Test verification methods.
   389→
   390→### UI Feature Workflow
   391→```
   392→/spec → /exec → /test → /qa
   393→```
   394→
   395→### UI Feature with Tests
   396→```
   397→/spec → /testgen → /exec → /test → /qa
   398→```
   399→Combine `testgen` and `test` for UI features with testable ACs.
   400→
   401→### Bug Fix Workflow (Simple)
   402→```
   403→/exec → /qa
   404→```
   405→Skip `/spec` if the bug is well-defined and straightforward.
   406→
   407→### Complex Feature Workflow
   408→```
   409→/fullsolve <issue>
   410→```
   411→Runs complete workflow with automatic fix iterations.
   412→
   413→## Quick Reference
   414→
   415→| Issue Type | Labels | Workflow |
   416→|------------|--------|----------|
   417→| UI Feature | ui, frontend, admin | spec → exec → test → qa |
   418→| UI Feature with Tests | ui + enhancement | spec → testgen → exec → test → qa |
   419→| Backend Feature | backend, api | spec → exec → qa |
   420→| New Feature (testable) | enhancement, feature | spec → testgen → exec → qa |
   421→| Bug Fix | bug, fix | exec → qa (or full if complex) |
   422→| Complex Feature | complex, refactor | `--quality-loop` or fullsolve |
   423→| Documentation | docs | exec → qa |
   424→
   425→### Testgen Phase Detection
   426→
   427→**Include `testgen` in workflow when:**
   428→- Issue has `enhancement` or `feature` label AND
   429→- Issue is NOT a simple bug fix or docs-only change AND
   430→- Project has test infrastructure (Jest, Vitest, etc.)
   431→
   432→**Skip `testgen` when:**
   433→- Issue is `bug` or `fix` only (targeted tests added during exec)
   434→- Issue is `docs` only (no code tests needed)
   435→- All ACs use Manual Test or Browser Test verification
   436→
   437→**Quality Loop vs Fullsolve:**
   438→- `--quality-loop`: Enables auto-retry within `sequant run` (good for CI/automation)
   439→- `/fullsolve`: Interactive single-issue resolution with inline loops (good for manual work)
   440→
   441→## CLI Alternative
   442→
   443→Use `npx sequant run` for batch execution from the command line:
   444→
   445→```bash
   446→# Run workflow for single issue
   447→npx sequant run 152
   448→
   449→# Multiple issues in parallel
   450→npx sequant run 152 153 154
   451→
   452→# Sequential execution (respects dependencies)
   453→npx sequant run 152 153 --sequential
   454→
   455→# Chain mode (each issue branches from previous completed issue)
   456→npx sequant run 10 11 12 --sequential --chain
   457→
   458→# Chain mode with QA gate (pause if QA fails, prevent stale code)
   459→npx sequant run 10 11 12 --sequential --chain --qa-gate
   460→
   461→# Custom base branch (branch from feature branch instead of main)
   462→npx sequant run 117 --base feature/dashboard
   463→
   464→# Chain mode with custom base branch
   465→npx sequant run 117 118 119 --sequential --chain --base feature/dashboard
   466→
   467→# Custom phases
   468→npx sequant run 152 --phases spec,exec,qa
   469→
   470→# Quality loop (auto-retry on failures, max 3 iterations)
   471→npx sequant run 152 --quality-loop
   472→
   473→# Quality loop with custom iterations
   474→npx sequant run 152 --quality-loop --max-iterations 5
   475→
   476→# Dry run (shows what would execute)
   477→npx sequant run 152 --dry-run
   478→```
   479→
   480→### Custom Base Branch
   481→
   482→The `--base` flag specifies which branch to create worktrees from:
   483→
   484→```
   485→Without --base:           With --base feature/dashboard:
   486→origin/main               feature/dashboard
   487→    ├── #117                  ├── #117
   488→    ├── #118                  ├── #118
   489→    └── #119                  └── #119
   490→```
   491→
   492→**Use `--base` when:**
   493→- Working on issues for a feature integration branch
   494→- Issue references a parent branch (e.g., "Part of dashboard feature")
   495→- Project uses `.sequant/settings.json` with `run.defaultBase` configured
   496→- Issues should build on an existing feature branch
   497→
   498→**Do NOT use `--base` when:**
   499→- Issues should branch from main (default behavior)
   500→- Working on independent bug fixes or features
   501→
   502→### Chain Mode Explained
   503→
   504→The `--chain` flag (requires `--sequential`) creates dependent branches:
   505→
   506→```
   507→Without --chain:          With --chain:
   508→origin/main               origin/main
   509→    ├── #10                   └── #10 (merged)
   510→    ├── #11                       └── #11 (merged)
   511→    └── #12                           └── #12
   512→```
   513→
   514→**Use `--chain` when:**
   515→- Issues have explicit dependencies
   516→- Later issues build on earlier implementations
   517→- Order matters for correctness
   518→
   519→**Do NOT use `--chain` when:**
   520→- Issues are independent
   521→- Parallel execution is appropriate
   522→- Issues can be merged in any order
   523→
   524→> **Tip:** Install globally with `npm install -g sequant` to omit the `npx` prefix.
   525→
   526→## Edge Cases
   527→
   528→### Multiple Issues with Different Types
   529→
   530→When solving multiple issues with mixed types, recommend running them separately:
   531→
   532→```markdown
   533→These issues have different requirements. Run separately:
   534→
   535→**UI Issues (with browser testing):**
   536→/fullsolve 152
   537→
   538→**Backend Issues:**
   539→/fullsolve 153
   540→```
   541→
   542→### Issue with Dependencies
   543→
   544→If issues depend on each other:
   545→
   546→```markdown
   547→⚠️ Issue #154 depends on #153. Run in order:
   548→
   549→1. /fullsolve 153
   550→2. (Wait for PR merge)
   551→3. /fullsolve 154
   552→```
   553→
   554→---
   555→
   556→## State Tracking
   557→
   558→**IMPORTANT:** `/solve` initializes issue state when analyzing issues.
   559→
   560→### State Updates
   561→
   562→When analyzing issues, initialize state tracking so the dashboard can show planned work:
   563→
   564→**Initialize each issue being analyzed:**
   565→```bash
   566→# Get issue title
   567→TITLE=$(gh issue view <issue-number> --json title -q '.title')
   568→
   569→# Initialize state (if not already tracked)
   570→npx tsx scripts/state/update.ts init <issue-number> "$TITLE"
   571→```
   572→
   573→**Note:** `/solve` only initializes issues - actual phase tracking happens during workflow execution (`/fullsolve`, `sequant run`, or individual skills).
   574→
   575→---
   576→
   577→## Output Verification
   578→
   579→**Before responding, verify your output includes ALL of these:**
   580→
   581→- [ ] **Header Box** — ASCII box with `sequant solve` and full command
   582→- [ ] **Issues List** — Each issue with dot leaders: `#N  Title ··· labels → workflow`
   583→- [ ] **Flags Table** — ALL five flags (-q, --chain, --qa-gate, --base, --testgen) with ✓/✗ and reasoning
   584→- [ ] **Why Section** — 3-5 bullet points explaining decisions
   585→- [ ] **Also Consider** — (conditional) Curated alternatives if applicable
   586→- [ ] **Conflict Warning** — (conditional) If in-flight work overlaps
   587→- [ ] **Line Count** — Total ≤25 lines (excluding conflict warnings)
   588→
   589→**DO NOT respond until all items are verified.**
   590→

content.content:
1→# Sequant
     2→
     3→**Workflow automation for [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code).**
     4→
     5→Solve GitHub issues with structured phases and quality gates — from issue to merge-ready PR.
     6→
     7→[![npm version](https://img.shields.io/npm/v/sequant.svg)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/sequant)
     8→[![License: MIT](https://img.shields.io/badge/License-MIT-green.svg)](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT)
     9→
    10→## Quick Start
    11→
    12→### Install
    13→
    14→```bash
    15→# In your project directory
    16→npm install sequant
    17→npx sequant init     # Install skills to your project
    18→npx sequant doctor   # Verify setup
    19→```
    20→
    21→To update:
    22→```bash
    23→npm update sequant
    24→```
    25→
    26→### Start Using
    27→
    28→Then in Claude Code:
    29→
    30→```
    31→/fullsolve 123    # Solve issue #123 end-to-end
    32→```
    33→
    34→Or step-by-step:
    35→
    36→```
    37→/spec 123    # Plan implementation
    38→/exec 123    # Build in isolated worktree
    39→/qa 123      # Review before merge
    40→```
    41→
    42→### Prerequisites
    43→
    44→**Required:**
    45→- [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code) — AI coding assistant
    46→- [GitHub CLI](https://cli.github.com/) — run `gh auth login`
    47→- Git (for worktree-based isolation)
    48→
    49→**For npm installation:**
    50→- Node.js 18+
    51→
    52→**Optional MCP servers (enhanced features):**
    53→- `chrome-devtools` — enables `/test` for browser-based UI testing
    54→- `sequential-thinking` — enhanced reasoning for complex decisions
    55→- `context7` — library documentation lookup
    56→
    57→> **Note:** Sequant is optimized for Node.js/TypeScript projects. The worktree workflow works with any git repository.
    58→
    59→---
    60→
    61→## How It Works
    62→
    63→Sequant adds slash commands to Claude Code that enforce a structured workflow:
    64→
    65→```
    66→┌─────────┐    ┌─────────┐    ┌─────────┐    ┌─────────┐
    67→│  /spec  │───▶│  /exec  │───▶│  /test  │───▶│   /qa   │───▶ Merge
    68→└─────────┘    └─────────┘    └─────────┘    └─────────┘
    69→     │              │              │              │
    70→     ▼              ▼              ▼              ▼
    71→   Plan          Build        Verify (UI)     Review
    72→```
    73→
    74→> `/test` is optional — used for UI features when Chrome DevTools MCP is available.
    75→
    76→### Worktree Isolation
    77→
    78→Sequant uses Git worktrees to isolate each issue's work:
    79→
    80→```
    81→your-project/           # Main repo (stays on main branch)
    82→../worktrees/
    83→  feature/
    84→    123-add-login/     # Issue #123 worktree (feature branch)
    85→    456-fix-bug/       # Issue #456 worktree (feature branch)
    86→```
    87→
    88→**Why worktrees?**
    89→- Work on multiple issues simultaneously
    90→- Never pollute your main branch
    91→- Each issue has its own dependencies and build
    92→- Safe to discard failed experiments
    93→
    94→### Quality Gates
    95→
    96→Every `/qa` runs automated checks:
    97→
    98→- **AC Adherence** — Code verified against acceptance criteria
    99→- **Type Safety** — Detects `any`, `as any`, missing types
   100→- **Security Scans** — OWASP-style vulnerability detection
   101→- **Semgrep Static Analysis** — Stack-aware rulesets, custom rules via `.sequant/semgrep-rules.yaml`
   102→- **Scope Analysis** — Flags changes outside issue scope
   103→- **Execution Evidence** — Scripts/CLI must pass smoke tests
   104→- **Test Quality** — Validates test coverage and mock hygiene
   105→- **Anti-Pattern Detection** — Catches N+1 queries, empty catch blocks, stale dependencies
   106→
   107→When checks fail, `/loop` automatically fixes and re-runs (up to 3x).
   108→
   109→---
   110→
   111→## Two Ways to Use
   112→
   113→### Interactive (Claude Code)
   114→
   115→Type commands directly in Claude Code chat:
   116→
   117→```
   118→/fullsolve 123              # Complete pipeline
   119→/spec 123 → /exec → /qa     # Step by step
   120→```
   121→
   122→### Headless (CLI)
   123→
   124→Run without Claude Code UI:
   125→
   126→```bash
   127→npx sequant run 123              # Single issue
   128→npx sequant run 1 2 3            # Batch (parallel)
   129→npx sequant run 123 --quality-loop
   130→npx sequant run 123 --base feature/dashboard  # Custom base branch
   131→```
   132→
   133→---
   134→
   135→## Commands
   136→
   137→### Core Workflow
   138→
   139→| Command | Purpose |
   140→|---------|---------|
   141→| `/spec` | Plan implementation, draft acceptance criteria |
   142→| `/exec` | Implement in isolated git worktree |
   143→| `/test` | Browser-based UI testing (optional) |
   144→| `/qa` | Code review and quality gate |
   145→
   146→### Automation
   147→
   148→| Command | Purpose |
   149→|---------|---------|
   150→| `/fullsolve` | Complete pipeline in one command |
   151→| `/solve` | Recommend optimal workflow for issue |
   152→| `/loop` | Fix iteration when checks fail |
   153→
   154→### Integration
   155→
   156→| Command | Purpose |
   157→|---------|---------|
   158→| `/testgen` | Generate test stubs from spec |
   159→| `/verify` | CLI/script execution verification |
   160→| `/setup` | Initialize Sequant in a project |
   161→
   162→### Utilities
   163→
   164→| Command | Purpose |
   165→|---------|---------|
   166→| `/assess` | Issue triage and status assessment |
   167→| `/docs` | Generate feature documentation |
   168→| `/clean` | Repository cleanup |
   169→| `/improve` | Codebase analysis and improvement discovery |
   170→| `/security-review` | Deep security analysis |
   171→| `/reflect` | Workflow improvement analysis |
   172→
   173→---
   174→
   175→## CLI Commands
   176→
   177→```bash
   178→npx sequant init              # Initialize in project
   179→npx sequant update            # Update skill templates
   180→npx sequant doctor            # Check installation
   181→npx sequant status            # Show version and config
   182→npx sequant run <issues...>   # Execute workflow
   183→npx sequant state <cmd>       # Manage workflow state (init/rebuild/clean)
   184→npx sequant stats             # View local workflow analytics
   185→npx sequant dashboard         # Launch real-time workflow dashboard
   186→```
   187→
   188→See [Run Command Options](docs/reference/run-command.md), [State Command](docs/reference/state-command.md), and [Analytics](docs/reference/analytics.md) for details.
   189→
   190→---
   191→
   192→## Configuration
   193→
   194→```json
   195→// .sequant/settings.json
   196→{
   197→  "run": {
   198→    "qualityLoop": false,
   199→    "maxIterations": 3,
   200→    "defaultBase": "feature/dashboard"  // Optional: custom default base branch
   201→  }
   202→}
   203→```
   204→
   205→See [Customization Guide](docs/guides/customization.md) for all options.
   206→
   207→---
   208→
   209→## Platform Support
   210→
   211→| Platform | Status |
   212→|----------|--------|
   213→| macOS | ✅ Full support |
   214→| Linux | ✅ Full support |
   215→| Windows WSL | ✅ Full support |
   216→| Windows Native | ⚠️ CLI only |
   217→
   218→---
   219→
   220→## Documentation
   221→
   222→- [Quickstart](docs/guides/quickstart.md) — 5-minute guide
   223→- [Complete Workflow](docs/guides/workflow.md) — Full workflow including post-QA patterns
   224→- [Getting Started](docs/getting-started/installation.md)
   225→- [What We've Built](docs/internal/what-weve-built.md) — Comprehensive project overview
   226→- [What Is Sequant](docs/concepts/what-is-sequant.md) — Elevator pitch, pipeline diagram, architecture
   227→- [Workflow Concepts](docs/concepts/workflow-phases.md)
   228→- [Run Command](docs/reference/run-command.md)
   229→- [Git Workflows](docs/guides/git-workflows.md)
   230→- [Customization](docs/guides/customization.md)
   231→- [Troubleshooting](docs/troubleshooting.md)
   232→
   233→Stack guides: [Next.js](docs/stacks/nextjs.md) · [Rust](docs/stacks/rust.md) · [Python](docs/stacks/python.md) · [Go](docs/stacks/go.md)
   234→
   235→---
   236→
   237→## Feedback & Contributing
   238→
   239→### Reporting Issues
   240→
   241→- **Bug reports:** [Bug template](https://github.com/sequant-io/sequant/issues/new?template=bug.yml)
   242→- **Feature requests:** [Feature template](https://github.com/sequant-io/sequant/issues/new?template=feature.yml)
   243→- **Questions:** [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/sequant-io/sequant/discussions)
   244→
   245→### Using `/improve` for Feedback
   246→
   247→Run `/improve` in Claude Code to analyze your codebase and create structured issues:
   248→
   249→```
   250→/improve              # Analyze entire codebase
   251→/improve security     # Focus on security concerns
   252→/improve tests        # Find test coverage gaps
   253→```
   254→
   255→The skill will present findings and offer to create GitHub issues automatically.
   256→
   257→### Contributing
   258→
   259→See [CONTRIBUTING.md](CONTRIBUTING.md) for development setup and guidelines.
   260→
   261→### Telemetry
   262→
   263→Sequant does not collect any usage telemetry. See [docs/reference/telemetry.md](docs/reference/telemetry.md) for details.
   264→
   265→---
   266→
   267→## License
   268→
   269→MIT
   270→

content.content:
1→---
     2→name: solve
     3→description: "Generate the recommended workflow for one or more GitHub issues"
     4→license: MIT
     5→metadata:
     6→  author: sequant
     7→  version: "1.0"
     8→allowed-tools:
     9→  - Bash(gh issue view:*)
    10→---
    11→
    12→# Solve Command Generator
    13→
    14→You are the "Solve Command Generator" for the current repository.
    15→
    16→## Purpose
    17→
    18→When invoked as `/solve <issue-numbers>`, your job is to:
    19→
    20→1. Analyze the provided issue number(s)
    21→2. Check labels to determine issue type
    22→3. Recommend the optimal workflow sequence
    23→4. **Output using the EXACT template format** (see Output Template section)
    24→
    25→## CRITICAL: Output Requirements
    26→
    27→**You MUST follow the Output Template exactly.** Key requirements:
    28→
    29→1. **Use the ASCII box header** with `npx sequant run <ISSUES> <FLAGS>`
    30→2. **Include the Flags Table** showing ALL flags with ✓/✗:
    31→   - `-q` (quality-loop) — **Default to ✓** unless trivial bug fix
    32→   - `--chain` — ✓ if dependencies between issues
    33→   - `--qa-gate` — ✓ if chain with 3+ issues
    34→   - `--base` — ✓ if feature branch context
    35→   - `--testgen` — ✓ if new feature needs tests
    36→3. **Quality loop (`-q`) should be ✓ (enabled)** for most issues — only skip for simple bug fixes or docs-only changes
    37→
    38→**DO NOT** output free-form prose. Use the structured template.
    39→
    40→## Behavior
    41→
    42→### Invocation Formats
    43→
    44→- `/solve 152` - Single issue
    45→- `/solve 152 153 154` - Multiple issues
    46→
    47→### Detection Logic
    48→
    49→For each issue, check GitHub labels to determine the workflow:
    50→
    51→```bash
    52→gh issue view <issue-number> --json labels --jq '.labels[].name'
    53→```
    54→
    55→**UI/Frontend Issues** (labels: `ui`, `frontend`, `admin`):
    56→- Include `/test` phase for browser testing
    57→
    58→**Backend/API Issues** (labels: `backend`, `api`, `cli`):
    59→- Skip browser testing, focus on unit/integration tests
    60→
    61→**Bug Fixes** (labels: `bug`, `fix`):
    62→- May need simpler workflow, possibly skip `/spec`
    63→
    64→**Complex Issues** (labels: `complex`, `refactor`, `breaking`, `major`):
    65→- Recommend `--quality-loop` flag for auto-retry on failures
    66→- Quality loop auto-enables for these labels in `sequant run`
    67→
    68→**New Features** (labels: `enhancement`, `feature`):
    69→- Include `testgen` phase when ACs need automated tests
    70→- Workflow: `spec → testgen → exec → qa`
    71→
    72→### Quality Loop Detection
    73→
    74→Quality loop (`--quality-loop` or `-q`) provides automatic fix iterations when phases fail. **Recommend quality loop broadly** for any non-trivial work.
    75→
    76→**Always recommend `--quality-loop` when:**
    77→- Labels include: `complex`, `refactor`, `breaking`, `major` (auto-enabled)
    78→- Labels include: `enhancement`, `feature` (new functionality)
    79→- Issue involves multiple files or components
    80→- Issue title contains: "add", "implement", "create", "refactor", "update", "overhaul", "redesign", "improve", "rework", "revamp", "migrate", "convert", "design", "build", "develop"
    81→- Issue is NOT a simple bug fix with `bug` or `fix` label only
    82→- **Default: recommend quality loop unless explicitly trivial** — most issues benefit from retry capability
    83→
    84→**Skip quality loop recommendation only when:**
    85→- Simple bug fix (only `bug` or `fix` label, no other labels)
    86→- Documentation-only changes (`docs` label only)
    87→- Issue explicitly marked as trivial
    88→
    89→**Quality loop benefits:**
    90→- Auto-retries failed phases up to 3 times
    91→- Catches intermittent test failures
    92→- Handles build issues from dependency changes
    93→- Reduces manual intervention for recoverable errors
    94→
    95→### Feature Branch Detection
    96→
    97→When analyzing issues, check if `--base` flag should be recommended.
    98→
    99→**Check for feature branch indicators:**
   100→
   101→```bash
   102→# Check for feature branch references in issue body
   103→gh issue view <issue-number> --json body --jq '.body' | grep -iE "(feature/|branch from|based on|part of.*feature)"
   104→
   105→# Check issue labels for feature context
   106→gh issue view <issue-number> --json labels --jq '.labels[].name' | grep -iE "(dashboard|feature-|epic-)"
   107→
   108→# Check if project has defaultBase configured
   109→# Use the Read tool to check project settings
   110→Read(file_path=".sequant/settings.json")
   111→# Extract .run.defaultBase from the JSON
   112→```
   113→
   114→**Recommend `--base <branch>` when:**
   115→- Issue body references a feature branch (e.g., "Part of dashboard feature")
   116→- Issue is labeled with a feature epic label (e.g., `dashboard`, `epic-auth`)
   117→- Multiple related issues reference the same parent feature
   118→- Project has `run.defaultBase` configured in settings
   119→
   120→**Do NOT recommend `--base` when:**
   121→- Issue should branch from main (default, most common)
   122→- No feature branch context detected
   123→- Issue is a standalone bug fix or independent feature
   124→
   125→### Chain Mode Detection
   126→
   127→When analyzing multiple issues, determine if `--chain` flag should be recommended.
   128→
   129→**Check for chain indicators:**
   130→
   131→```bash
   132→# Check for dependency keywords in issue body
   133→gh issue view <issue-number> --json body --jq '.body' | grep -iE "(depends on|blocked by|requires|after #|builds on)"
   134→
   135→# Check for sequence labels
   136→gh issue view <issue-number> --json labels --jq '.labels[].name' | grep -iE "(part-[0-9]|step-[0-9]|phase-[0-9])"
   137→
   138→# Check for related issue references
   139→gh issue view <issue-number> --json body --jq '.body' | grep -oE "#[0-9]+"
   140→```
   141→
   142→**Recommend `--chain` when:**
   143→- Multiple issues have explicit dependencies (e.g., "depends on #123")
   144→- Issues are labeled as parts of a sequence (e.g., `part-1`, `part-2`)
   145→- Issue titles indicate sequence (e.g., "Part 1:", "Step 2:")
   146→- Issues reference each other in their bodies
   147→- Issues modify the same files in a specific order
   148→
   149→**Do NOT recommend `--chain` when:**
   150→- Single issue (chain requires 2+ issues)
   151→- Issues are independent (no shared files or dependencies)
   152→- Issues touch completely different areas of codebase
   153→- Parallel batch mode is more appropriate (unrelated issues)
   154→
   155→### QA Gate Detection
   156→
   157→When recommending `--chain`, also consider if `--qa-gate` should be added.
   158→
   159→**Recommend `--qa-gate` when:**
   160→- Chain has 3+ issues (longer chains have higher stale code risk)
   161→- Issues have tight dependencies (later issues heavily rely on earlier ones)
   162→- Issues modify the same files across the chain
   163→- Production-critical or high-risk changes
   164→
   165→**Do NOT recommend `--qa-gate` when:**
   166→- Chain has only 2 issues (lower risk)
   167→- Issues are mostly independent despite chain structure
   168→- Speed is prioritized over safety
   169→- Simple, low-risk changes
   170→
   171→**Chain structure visualization:**
   172→```
   173→origin/main → #10 → #11 → #12
   174→              │      │      │
   175→              └──────┴──────┴── Each branch builds on previous
   176→```
   177→
   178→## Output Format
   179→
   180→**Design Principles:**
   181→- Lead with the recommendation (command first, top-down)
   182→- Show all flag decisions explicitly with reasoning
   183→- Be concise — signal over prose
   184→- Visual hierarchy using ASCII boxes and lines
   185→- Max ~25 lines (excluding conflict warnings)
   186→
   187→**Required Sections (in order):**
   188→
   189→1. **Header Box** — Command recommendation prominently displayed
   190→2. **Issues List** — Compact: `#N  Title ··· labels → workflow`
   191→3. **Flags Table** — ALL flags with ✓/✗ and one-line reasoning
   192→4. **Why Section** — 3-5 bullet points explaining key decisions
   193→5. **Also Consider** — Conditional curated alternatives (0-3 items)
   194→6. **Conflict Warning** — Only if in-flight work overlaps (conditional)
   195→
   196→---
   197→
   198→## Conflict Detection
   199→
   200→Before generating output, check for in-flight work that may conflict:
   201→
   202→```bash
   203→# List open worktrees
   204→git worktree list --porcelain 2>/dev/null | grep "^worktree" | cut -d' ' -f2
   205→
   206→# For each worktree, get changed files
   207→git -C <worktree-path> diff --name-only main...HEAD 2>/dev/null
   208→```
   209→
   210→**If overlap detected** with files this issue likely touches, include warning:
   211→```
   212→⚠ Conflict risk: #45 (open) modifies lib/auth/* — coordinate or wait
   213→```
   214→
   215→---
   216→
   217→## "Also Consider" Logic
   218→
   219→Only show alternatives representing genuine trade-offs. Max 2-3 items.
   220→
   221→| Condition | Show Alternative |
   222→|-----------|------------------|
   223→| Complex issues OR user unfamiliar with sequant | `--dry-run` (preview before executing) |
   224→| UI-adjacent AND test phase not included | `--phases +test` (add browser testing) |
   225→| Mild dependency risk between issues | `--sequential` (run one at a time) |
   226→| Dependencies ambiguous | Show both parallel and `--chain` options |
   227→
   228→**Rules:**
   229→- Omit section entirely if nothing worth showing
   230→- Never list every flag — only curated, contextual options
   231→- Each alternative needs one-line explanation
   232→
   233→---
   234→
   235→## Output Template
   236→
   237→You MUST use this exact structure:
   238→
   239→```
   240→╭──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╮
   241→│  sequant solve                                               │
   242→│                                                              │
   243→│  npx sequant run <ISSUES> <FLAGS>                            │
   244→╰──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╯
   245→
   246→#<N>  <Title truncated to ~35 chars> ·········· <labels> → <workflow>
   247→#<N>  <Title truncated to ~35 chars> ·········· <labels> → <workflow>
   248→
   249→┌─ Flags ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
   250→│  -q  quality-loop   ✓/✗  <one-line reasoning>                │
   251→│  --chain            ✓/✗  <one-line reasoning>                │
   252→│  --qa-gate          ✓/✗  <one-line reasoning>                │
   253→│  --base             ✓/✗  <one-line reasoning>                │
   254→│  --testgen          ✓/✗  <one-line reasoning>                │
   255→└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
   256→
   257→Why this workflow:
   258→  • <reason 1>
   259→  • <reason 2>
   260→  • <reason 3>
   261→
   262→<!-- CONDITIONAL: Only if alternatives worth showing -->
   263→Also consider:
   264→  <flag>     <one-line explanation>
   265→  <flag>     <one-line explanation>
   266→
   267→<!-- CONDITIONAL: Only if conflict detected -->
   268→⚠ Conflict risk: #<N> (open) modifies <path> — coordinate or wait
   269→```
   270→
   271→---
   272→
   273→### Example Output (Independent Issues)
   274→
   275→```
   276→╭──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╮
   277→│  sequant solve                                               │
   278→│                                                              │
   279→│  npx sequant run 152 153 -q                                  │
   280→╰──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╯
   281→
   282→#152  Add user dashboard ······················ ui → spec → testgen → exec → test → qa
   283→#153  Refactor auth module ···················· backend → spec → exec → qa
   284→
   285→┌─ Flags ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
   286→│  -q  quality-loop   ✓  refactor label auto-enables retry     │
   287→│  --chain            ✗  independent (different codepaths)     │
   288→│  --qa-gate          ✗  no chain mode                         │
   289→│  --base             ✗  branching from main                   │
   290→│  --testgen          ✓  #152 has testable ACs (Unit Tests)    │
   291→└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
   292→
   293→Why this workflow:
   294→  • #152 has ui label → includes /test for browser verification
   295→  • #152 has testable ACs → includes /testgen for test stubs
   296→  • #153 has refactor label → quality loop auto-enabled
   297→  • No shared files → safe to parallelize
   298→
   299→Also consider:
   300→  --dry-run     Preview execution before running
   301→```
   302→
   303→---
   304→
   305→### Example Output (Dependent Issues — Chain)
   306→
   307→```
   308→╭──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╮
   309→│  sequant solve                                               │
   310→│                                                              │
   311→│  npx sequant run 10 11 12 --sequential --chain --qa-gate -q  │
   312→╰──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╯
   313→
   314→#10  Add auth middleware ······················ backend → spec → testgen → exec → qa
   315→#11  Add login page ··························· ui → spec → testgen → exec → test → qa
   316→#12  Add logout functionality ················· ui → spec → exec → test → qa
   317→
   318→┌─ Flags ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
   319→│  -q  quality-loop   ✓  multi-step implementation             │
   320→│  --chain            ✓  #11 depends on #10, #12 depends on #11│
   321→│  --qa-gate          ✓  3 issues with tight dependencies      │
   322→│  --base             ✗  branching from main                   │
   323→│  --testgen          ✓  #10, #11 have Unit Test ACs           │
   324→└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
   325→
   326→Chain structure:
   327→  main → #10 → #11 → #12
   328→
   329→Why this workflow:
   330→  • Explicit dependencies detected in issue bodies
   331→  • Chain ensures each branch builds on previous
   332→  • QA gate prevents stale code in downstream issues
   333→  • UI issues (#11, #12) include /test phase
   334→  • #10, #11 have testable ACs → include /testgen
   335→```
   336→
   337→---
   338→
   339→### Example Output (With Conflict Warning)
   340→
   341→```
   342→╭──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╮
   343→│  sequant solve                                               │
   344→│                                                              │
   345→│  npx sequant run 85 -q                                       │
   346→╰──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╯
   347→
   348→#85  Update auth cookie handling ·············· bug → exec → qa
   349→
   350→┌─ Flags ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
   351→│  -q  quality-loop   ✓  auth changes benefit from retry       │
   352→│  --chain            ✗  single issue                          │
   353→│  --qa-gate          ✗  no chain mode                         │
   354→│  --base             ✗  branching from main                   │
   355→│  --testgen          ✗  bug fix (targeted tests in exec)      │
   356→└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
   357→
   358→Why this workflow:
   359→  • Bug fix with clear AC → skip /spec
   360→  • Bug fix → skip /testgen (targeted tests added during exec)
   361→  • Single issue → no chain needed
   362→
   363→⚠ Conflict risk: #82 (open) modifies lib/auth/cookies.ts — coordinate or wait
   364→```
   365→
   366→## Workflow Selection Logic
   367→
   368→**Note:** `npx sequant run` now uses **spec-driven phase detection**. It runs `/spec` first, which analyzes the issue and outputs a `## Recommended Workflow` section. The CLI then parses this to determine subsequent phases.
   369→
   370→### How It Works
   371→
   372→1. **Bug fixes** (labels: `bug`, `fix`) → Skip spec, run `exec → qa` directly
   373→2. **All other issues** → Run `/spec` first, which recommends phases based on:
   374→   - UI/frontend changes → Add `test` phase
   375→   - Complex refactors → Enable quality loop
   376→   - Security-sensitive → Add `security-review` phase
   377→   - New features with testable ACs → Add `testgen` phase
   378→
   379→### Standard Workflow (Most Issues)
   380→```
   381→/spec → /exec → /qa
   382→```
   383→
   384→### Feature with Testable ACs
   385→```
   386→/spec → /testgen → /exec → /qa
   387→```
   388→Include `testgen` when ACs have Unit Test or Integration Test verification methods.
   389→
   390→### UI Feature Workflow
   391→```
   392→/spec → /exec → /test → /qa
   393→```
   394→
   395→### UI Feature with Tests
   396→```
   397→/spec → /testgen → /exec → /test → /qa
   398→```
   399→Combine `testgen` and `test` for UI features with testable ACs.
   400→
   401→### Bug Fix Workflow (Simple)
   402→```
   403→/exec → /qa
   404→```
   405→Skip `/spec` if the bug is well-defined and straightforward.
   406→
   407→### Complex Feature Workflow
   408→```
   409→/fullsolve <issue>
   410→```
   411→Runs complete workflow with automatic fix iterations.
   412→
   413→## Quick Reference
   414→
   415→| Issue Type | Labels | Workflow |
   416→|------------|--------|----------|
   417→| UI Feature | ui, frontend, admin | spec → exec → test → qa |
   418→| UI Feature with Tests | ui + enhancement | spec → testgen → exec → test → qa |
   419→| Backend Feature | backend, api | spec → exec → qa |
   420→| New Feature (testable) | enhancement, feature | spec → testgen → exec → qa |
   421→| Bug Fix | bug, fix | exec → qa (or full if complex) |
   422→| Complex Feature | complex, refactor | `--quality-loop` or fullsolve |
   423→| Documentation | docs | exec → qa |
   424→
   425→### Testgen Phase Detection
   426→
   427→**Include `testgen` in workflow when:**
   428→- Issue has `enhancement` or `feature` label AND
   429→- Issue is NOT a simple bug fix or docs-only change AND
   430→- Project has test infrastructure (Jest, Vitest, etc.)
   431→
   432→**Skip `testgen` when:**
   433→- Issue is `bug` or `fix` only (targeted tests added during exec)
   434→- Issue is `docs` only (no code tests needed)
   435→- All ACs use Manual Test or Browser Test verification
   436→
   437→**Quality Loop vs Fullsolve:**
   438→- `--quality-loop`: Enables auto-retry within `sequant run` (good for CI/automation)
   439→- `/fullsolve`: Interactive single-issue resolution with inline loops (good for manual work)
   440→
   441→## CLI Alternative
   442→
   443→Use `npx sequant run` for batch execution from the command line:
   444→
   445→```bash
   446→# Run workflow for single issue
   447→npx sequant run 152
   448→
   449→# Multiple issues in parallel
   450→npx sequant run 152 153 154
   451→
   452→# Sequential execution (respects dependencies)
   453→npx sequant run 152 153 --sequential
   454→
   455→# Chain mode (each issue branches from previous completed issue)
   456→npx sequant run 10 11 12 --sequential --chain
   457→
   458→# Chain mode with QA gate (pause if QA fails, prevent stale code)
   459→npx sequant run 10 11 12 --sequential --chain --qa-gate
   460→
   461→# Custom base branch (branch from feature branch instead of main)
   462→npx sequant run 117 --base feature/dashboard
   463→
   464→# Chain mode with custom base branch
   465→npx sequant run 117 118 119 --sequential --chain --base feature/dashboard
   466→
   467→# Custom phases
   468→npx sequant run 152 --phases spec,exec,qa
   469→
   470→# Quality loop (auto-retry on failures, max 3 iterations)
   471→npx sequant run 152 --quality-loop
   472→
   473→# Quality loop with custom iterations
   474→npx sequant run 152 --quality-loop --max-iterations 5
   475→
   476→# Dry run (shows what would execute)
   477→npx sequant run 152 --dry-run
   478→```
   479→
   480→### Custom Base Branch
   481→
   482→The `--base` flag specifies which branch to create worktrees from:
   483→
   484→```
   485→Without --base:           With --base feature/dashboard:
   486→origin/main               feature/dashboard
   487→    ├── #117                  ├── #117
   488→    ├── #118                  ├── #118
   489→    └── #119                  └── #119
   490→```
   491→
   492→**Use `--base` when:**
   493→- Working on issues for a feature integration branch
   494→- Issue references a parent branch (e.g., "Part of dashboard feature")
   495→- Project uses `.sequant/settings.json` with `run.defaultBase` configured
   496→- Issues should build on an existing feature branch
   497→
   498→**Do NOT use `--base` when:**
   499→- Issues should branch from main (default behavior)
   500→- Working on independent bug fixes or features
   501→
   502→### Chain Mode Explained
   503→
   504→The `--chain` flag (requires `--sequential`) creates dependent branches:
   505→
   506→```
   507→Without --chain:          With --chain:
   508→origin/main               origin/main
   509→    ├── #10                   └── #10 (merged)
   510→    ├── #11                       └── #11 (merged)
   511→    └── #12                           └── #12
   512→```
   513→
   514→**Use `--chain` when:**
   515→- Issues have explicit dependencies
   516→- Later issues build on earlier implementations
   517→- Order matters for correctness
   518→
   519→**Do NOT use `--chain` when:**
   520→- Issues are independent
   521→- Parallel execution is appropriate
   522→- Issues can be merged in any order
   523→
   524→> **Tip:** Install globally with `npm install -g sequant` to omit the `npx` prefix.
   525→
   526→## Edge Cases
   527→
   528→### Multiple Issues with Different Types
   529→
   530→When solving multiple issues with mixed types, recommend running them separately:
   531→
   532→```markdown
   533→These issues have different requirements. Run separately:
   534→
   535→**UI Issues (with browser testing):**
   536→/fullsolve 152
   537→
   538→**Backend Issues:**
   539→/fullsolve 153
   540→```
   541→
   542→### Issue with Dependencies
   543→
   544→If issues depend on each other:
   545→
   546→```markdown
   547→⚠️ Issue #154 depends on #153. Run in order:
   548→
   549→1. /fullsolve 153
   550→2. (Wait for PR merge)
   551→3. /fullsolve 154
   552→```
   553→
   554→---
   555→
   556→## State Tracking
   557→
   558→**IMPORTANT:** `/solve` initializes issue state when analyzing issues.
   559→
   560→### State Updates
   561→
   562→When analyzing issues, initialize state tracking so the dashboard can show planned work:
   563→
   564→**Initialize each issue being analyzed:**
   565→```bash
   566→# Get issue title
   567→TITLE=$(gh issue view <issue-number> --json title -q '.title')
   568→
   569→# Initialize state (if not already tracked)
   570→npx tsx scripts/state/update.ts init <issue-number> "$TITLE"
   571→```
   572→
   573→**Note:** `/solve` only initializes issues - actual phase tracking happens during workflow execution (`/fullsolve`, `sequant run`, or individual skills).
   574→
   575→---
   576→
   577→## Output Verification
   578→
   579→**Before responding, verify your output includes ALL of these:**
   580→
   581→- [ ] **Header Box** — ASCII box with `sequant solve` and full command
   582→- [ ] **Issues List** — Each issue with dot leaders: `#N  Title ··· labels → workflow`
   583→- [ ] **Flags Table** — ALL five flags (-q, --chain, --qa-gate, --base, --testgen) with ✓/✗ and reasoning
   584→- [ ] **Why Section** — 3-5 bullet points explaining decisions
   585→- [ ] **Also Consider** — (conditional) Curated alternatives if applicable
   586→- [ ] **Conflict Warning** — (conditional) If in-flight work overlaps
   587→- [ ] **Line Count** — Total ≤25 lines (excluding conflict warnings)
   588→
   589→**DO NOT respond until all items are verified.**
   590→
